item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description: And you haven't changed anything since you got the last one? Hmm... As far as comments go, the code is pretty clear about not allowing any to get by if comments are turned off for the entry in question.

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description: Haven't gotten any today... but I don't see any POST requests in my access log for the comments form, either.

item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description:

item.description: Do you have any plugins installed? If so, have you tried turning them off and seeing if you still get comments showing up for moderation?

item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description:
mysql> SELECT comment_type FROM wp_comments ORDER BY comment_ID DESC LIMIT 5; +--------------+ | comment_type | +--------------+ | | | | | | | | | | +--------------+ 5 rows in set (0.00 sec)

mysql>

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description:
SELECT comment_type FROM wp_comments ORDER BY comment_ID DESC LIMIT 5

That should give you the comment type for the five most recent comments/pings. (If you changed the table prefix in wp-config.php, then make sure you change "wp_" above.)

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description:
Strange. I had a similar problem two days ago: comments were off, but I still had to deal with a mess of comments awaiting moderation. I was getting one every few minutes. After I turned off pings, they stopped.

Could you check in the DB whether they are comments or trackbacks? It may help in determining why they are getting through...

item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #948 (Authors without e-mail specified cannot comment) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: If an author in WordPress doesn't have an e-mail address in their profile, and that author is logged in to WP, and the "require name and e-mail" setting is ON, that person will not be able to leave comments.

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description:
Well, firstly, certainly trackbacks should be clearly marked as such if they're not currently!

But I am indeed certain it's not that. I only have five entries in the blog ( ​http://caconym.org/blog/ ), and all of them have "allow comments" and "allow pings" unchecked, and yet I still am receiving moderation requests.

edited on: 02-22-05 04:56

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description:
Status changed

Are you certain these are not trackbacks? Trackbacks can be held for moderation just like comments, and will look the same.

This is still confusing, though... perhaps the issue is this: should trackbacks be clearly marked as such in the admin UI/notification emails/etc.?

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) created
item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description:
I get a few dozen "comment waiting for your approval" messages per day on comments which have comments turned off. All of these messages are for comments from spammers (mostly texas hold-em poker).

This is occuring even though comments are OFF for ALL entries. Not just off as in comments are turned off for future posts, but off as in I have verified that each individual entry (there's only five of them, so it's not difficult to check) has comments off. The entries say "comments off" in the blog's web page, and the checkbox for comments is unchecked for each of them - and yet every day I get more moderation requests for them.

Several other people are having this issue as well: see ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic.php?id=24313

item.title: Ticket #945 (pingback is always sent) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description:
A bit more information:

  • checking the option sets option_value to '1', unchchecking it to .
  • pingback is sent in both cases.
  • this is tested locally by linking to my own blog and linking to other blogs. option_value was set to but pingback was sent.
  • there are two places in post.php where pingback happens: in action-case 'post' and 'edit'.
  • in case 'edit' I added an error_log() which always wrote to the logfile, regardless of the setting in option_value. (but pingback was not sent, I guess because it was sent when being published?! the ping site is not in field 'pinged' table posts though...)
  • after adding " === '1'" to the if's logging and pinging stopped.

item.title: Ticket #945 (pingback is always sent) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #945 (pingback is always sent) created
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: Regardless of discussion-option "Attempt to notify [...]" links in entries always get pinged. I tried to fix this by making sure the option_value for default_pingback_flag really is '1' and not empty.

item.title: Ticket #941 (.htaccess generation fails) updated
item.dc:creator: chenu
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #941 (.htaccess generation fails) created
item.dc:creator: chenu
item.description:
My WP 1.5 install does not generate an .htaccess file. My host is running Apache 1.3 on FreeBSD. The Permalink page says that the new settings were saved.

I've had to run my site with a .htaccess file that I generated on my home server. The .htaccess file is chmod'ed to 666.

I saw thread in the support forum about a similar issue and they had changed part of the wp-includes.php as shown below: $is_apache = strstr($_SERVERSERVER_SOFTWARE?, 'Apache') ? 1 : 0; to $is_apache = 1;

I thought that this would help because my host spoofs the server header to say that the server software is Zeus instead of Apache.

item.title: Ticket #940 (CRUFT in get_postdata()) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #940 (CRUFT in get_postdata()) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
In functions.php, the get_postdata() function includes the line:

'Category' => $a_post->post_category,

which always returns zero, since the field "Category" in the posts table is no longer used.

See bug #239: ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=239

item.title: Ticket #939 (Fix in quicktag.js for browsers' selecting trailing space when double ...) created
item.dc:creator: Ozh
item.description: When double clicking a word in a text field, highlighted text includes trailing spaces if applicable (at least in Windows, can't check in Linux) This can lead to ugly html tagging : <em>hello </em>world <a href="link">hello </a>world

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
This is not a problem with MarsEdit or any particular XMLRPC client.

When the plugin hook for edit_post was added to wp_update_posts, the function was still returning $wpdb->affected_rows directly. The problem is that this value could change, depending on which actions were called by the edit_post hook. In my case for example, a plugin is updating tags, so if nothing changed there, $wpdb->affected_rows becomes 0; so 0 is returned, and xmlrpc.php thinks "whoops, the post wasn't edited".

I'm uploading a simple patch in a second.

item.title: Ticket #938 (maximum number of links in comment "exploit") updated
item.dc:creator: Ozh
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #938 (maximum number of links in comment "exploit") created
item.dc:creator: Ozh
item.description: Function 'check_comment' in comment-functions.php counts the number of 'http:' occurences. So a spammer can post as much links as wished if typed this way : <a href="crapsite.com">link</a>

I have been unable to reproduce the issue with WP 1.5 and Ecto 2.2.3. (I have, however, hit another bug, but that is not relevant to this bug here.)

item.title: Ticket #924 (RSS2 feed does not validate when using translation mo file) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
mysql2date() accepts an optional third argument that prevents translating the date via the locale tables when set to false. All feeds have been updated to pass a third argument of false to all invocations of mysql2date().

Also, the $use_b2configmonthsdays argument of mysql2date() has been renamed $translate and given a default value of true instead of 1.
